posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Can you describe more about what manipulation you need to perform?

A few other tips to help get answers faster:

When making a post, consider using fenced code blocks to put your code snippets in, it’ll make things much easier for others to read.

Consider using github.com to post full code samples - it will also help you track your code and its changes. When posting in forums, only provide the portions you believe are most relevant to the question. This serves two purposes - it reduces the work others have to do to understand your meaning, and forces you to think through which portions of code are relevant (which goes a long way toward forming a better question)

posts.cooked: What version of robotpy-apriltag do you have installed? Make sure you’ve got 2024.3.1.

posts.name: Jacob Fisher
posts.cooked: I am also having the same error apriltag.c:224:quick_decode_init(): Failed to allocate hamming decode table when using cameras + april tags. I didn’t have this error before I updated to WPILib 2024 (Java).

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Esdras01:

Failed to allocate hamming decode table

fisherjacobc:

Failed to allocate hamming decode table

I, too, am getting this error with Java 2024 WPILib VSCode example program. Did either @Esdras01 or @fisherjacobc get this working? thanks.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
That’s a memory allocation error. You could reduce the bitsCorrected parameter to AprilTagDetector.addFamily to reduce memory required.

2023 example used 0 bits corrected since it was a much smaller tag family.

posts.name: Jacob Fisher
posts.cooked: What is the recommended option for that?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: With a program slightly larger than the example, on the roboRIO (original - v1) 0 bits and 1 bit worked; 2 and 3 do not. Maybe on a roboRIO v2 or RPi you can go higher.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
It appears that for 36h11: Hamming 1 allocates (587 + 587 * 36) * 3 * 12 = 781KB Hamming 2 allocates (587 + 587 * 36 + 587 * 36 * 35) * 3 * 12 = 27.4 MB Hamming 3 allocates (587 + 587 * 36 + 587 * 36 * 35 + 587 * 36 * 35 * 34) * 3 * 12 = 932 MB

(reference: apriltag.c source code)

The Rio 1 only has 256 MB of total memory.  The Rio 2 only has 512 MB.

So I think the example is simply broken as it uses hamming 3; while it might work in sim, it will not work on Rio.  It should be changed to use hamming 2 on Rio 2 and hamming 1 on Rio 1.  I’ve opened an issue for this on allwpilib.
